render.tex: \title{Relation Meaning} \\ %text Meaning of a relation $R$ in sets $A$ and $B$ %

reason.tex:
%text A relation in sets $A$ and $B$ is an arbitrary subset of $A\times B$ which satisfies some condition. Consider the sets $A$ and $B$ where $A=\{1,2\}$, and $B=\{5,6,7\}$. All possible combinations of $A$ and $B$ are, % \begin{align} A\times B =& \{1,5\}, \{1,6\}, \{1,7\}, \\ &\{2,5\},\{2,6\},\{2,7\} \end{align} \\ %text If we define a Relation $R$ between $A$ and $B$ such that $R=\{(a,b):b=a+4\}$, not all the above pairs satisfy this condition. For instance, % \begin{align} \{1,6\}&\implies b=a+5 \\ \{2,5\}&\implies b=a+3 \end{align} \\ %text In fact the only pair that satisfies the condition for the relation is % \begin{align} \{3,5\}\because 5=3+2 \end{align} \\ %text \therefore the relation $R$ from $A$ to $B$ is $\{3,5\}$.
Note: A relation can also be in set $A$ alone. In this case, it would be a subset of $A\times A$. %
